newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Oct 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Oct 21.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Feverish negotiations are going on between the camps of Vice President Joseph Estrada and Sen Edgardo Angara for a possible team-up in the 1998 elections. (PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER)
- A U.S.Department of Defence report has confirmed the presence of hazardous military wastes, including cancer-causing asbestos, at the former Clark air base (INQUIRER)
- A woman was shot dead and eight Moro National Liberation Front members were wounded on the eve of special elections in Parang, Sulu on Sunday (MANILA STANDARD)
- The Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) "lost command" is massing its forces in various areas in Mindanao in preparation for a large-scale offensive, the military said. (THE PHILIPPINE STAR)
- The government expects additional tax revenues of at least 2.5 billion pesos a year from the planned restructuring of the automotive industry (INQUIRER)
- The Trade Union Congress of the Philippines is seeking a 45-peso across the board increase in wages (BUSINESSWORLD)

- The government's projection of an average 8.6 percent inflation rate by end-1996 is harder to achieve with the recent oil price increase and the spate of price adjustments to come, economist Benjamin Diokno said. (THE BUSINESS DAILY)

- The Philippine National Oil Co-Petrochemical Development Corp will have to deal with Congress to push its right to take the lead in the construction of the country's first naphtha cracker facility. (THE BUSINESS DAILY)
